QAPair.Question: What is (are) Volvulus - childhood ?
QAPair.Answer: A volvulus is a twisting of the intestine that can occur in childhood. It causes a blockage that may cut off blood flow. Part of the intestine may be damaged as a result.

QAPair.Question: What causes Volvulus - childhood ?
QAPair.Answer: A birth defect called intestinal malrotation can make an infant more likely to develop a volvulus. However, a volvulus can occur without this condition present. Volvulus due to malrotation occurs most often in the first year of life.

QAPair.Question: What are the symptoms of Volvulus - childhood ?
QAPair.Answer: Common symptoms of volvulus are: Bloody or dark red stools , Constipation or difficulty releasing stools, Distended abdomen , Pain or tenderness in the abdomen, Nausea or vomiting, Shock , Vomiting green material , Symptoms are very often severe and require emergency care. Early treatment can be critical for survival.

QAPair.Question: How to diagnose Volvulus - childhood ?
QAPair.Answer: Your health care provider may order the following tests to diagnose the condition: Barium enema , Blood tests to check electrolytes , CT scan , Stool guaiac (shows blood in the stool), Upper GI series ,

QAPair.Question: What are the treatments for Volvulus - childhood ?
QAPair.Answer: In some cases, colonoscopy can be used to correct the problem. This involves use of a flexible tube with a light on the end that is passed into the colon (large bowel) through the rectum. Emergency surgery is often needed to repair the volvulus. A surgical cut is made in the abdomen. The bowels are untwisted and the blood supply is restored. If a small segment of bowel is dead from a lack of blood flow (necrotic), it is removed. The ends of the bowel are then sewn together. Or, they are used to form a connection of the intestines to the outside of the body (colostomy or ileostomy). Bowel contents can be removed through this opening.

QAPair.Question: What is the outlook for Volvulus - childhood ?
QAPair.Answer: Most of the time, prompt diagnosis and treatment of volvulus leads to a good outcome. If the bowel is dead, the outlook is poor. The situation may be fatal, depending on how much of the bowel is dead.

QAPair.Question: What are the complications of Volvulus - childhood ?
QAPair.Answer: Possible complications of volvulus are: Secondary peritonitis , Short bowel syndrome (after removal of a large part of the small bowel) ,

QAPair.Question: Do I need to see a doctor for Volvulus - childhood ?
QAPair.Answer: This is an emergency condition. The symptoms of childhood volvulus develop quickly and the child will become very ill. Get medical attention right away if this happens.
